intro: Tapinanthus crispatulus, commonly known as the curly-stemmed dodder, is a parasitic flowering plant belonging to the Orobanchaceae family. It lacks true leaves and roots, relying entirely on its host for nutrients through specializedhaustoria structures. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that bloom in clusters, often on the stems of its host plants. Its stems are characterized by their distinctive, wavy, and curling appearance. Tapinanthus crispatulus is typically found in arid and semi-arid regions, where it attaches to various shrubs and herbs.
